Box 90, Wilton, Cleveland TS6 8JE, UK (Received 13 September 1993, revised manuscript received 20 December 1993 ) Abstract The effect of NiO loading (5-21 wt.-%) on the reduction of NiO/a-A1203 catalysts, prepared by multiple impregnation of nickel nitrate solution followed by calcination at 650, has been charac- terized using temperature-programmed reduction, isothermal hydrogen consumption, magnetization, X-ray diffraction, and electron microscopy. X-ray diffraction analysis of fresh catalysts indicated normal NiO crystallites about 30 nm in size. Studies from 270 to 350 show hydrogen consumption at lower temperatures is faster than the subsequent growth of nucleated clusters of nickel atoms into crystallites, with the rates of the two processes approaching each other at higher temperatures. As NiO loading increases, chemical reduction becomes more difficult but nickel crystallite growth is not affected. This decreased reducibility is believed due to A13 + ion incorporation into NiO surface layers during impregnation. Isothermal hydrogen consumption from 270 to 450 follows a shrinking core model with NiO crystallites decreasing progressively in size. Magnetic measurements show crystallite growth is dependent on diffusion-controlled nucleation. Decreasing hydrogen flow has a profound effect on chemical reduction and nucleation but not on growth. Similar results are found with added water vapor. X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscope measurements reveal 23 nm nickel crystallites with some evidence for A1-Ni alloy formation. A mechanism is proposed in which adsorbed water inhibits chemical reduction and nucleation, and foreign ions such as A13+ increase this effect. Key words: nickel oxide; reduction; steam reforming; water inhibition 1, Introduction Steam reforming is an important industrial process for production of synthesis gas from hydrocarbons [ 1 ]. Since these supports are formulated at high temperatures and have low surface areas, the most convenient method for depositing the active component is impregnation with nickel salts followed by calcination to oxide precursors. With proper procedures, high dispersions of nickel oxide are achieved, giving high activity, good resistance to deactivation, and high mechanical and thermal strength. Conditions for reduction of the nickel oxide to metallic nickel are important in practice [ 2]. The catalyst is either reduced directly with hydrogen-containing gases or auto-reduced with natural gas-steam mixtures [ 3 ]. To facilitate these operations, the catalyst should be reducible at relatively low temperatures. However, rapid reduction may lead to lower dispersions and poor activity at process conditions. Since the extent and kinetics of reduction and thermal stability are influenced by interaction of nickel oxide with support components, a thorough understanding of relationships between these factors is necessary for optimum catalyst design and process operation. There are many reports concerning reduction of bulk nickel oxide [4] in which the sigmoidal shape of reduction versus time curves suggest an induction period followed by autocatalytic reduction. Koga and Harrison [ 5 ] describe this induction process as generation of nickel atoms on the outer surface of NiO grains, followed by nucleation into nickel clusters, at which point hydrogen is rapidly dissociated by nickel and reduction proceeds rapidly into the grain by a shrinking core model. Reduction follows the sequence: (1) dissociation of hydrogen (2) surface diffusion of hydrogen atoms to a reactive center, (3) rupture of Ni-O bonds to produce Niatoms, (4) nucleation of Niatoms into metallic nickel clusters, (5) growth of nickel clusters into crystallites. Any one or combination of these steps together with removal of water may control the overall reaction rate and influence the form of the reduction rate equation. Other complications arising for supported catalysts include ( 1 ) morphology and acces- sibility of NiO grains, (2) particle shape and size, (3) pore size distribution, (4) support interaction, and (5) preferred orientation of the active component. Although it has been known for some time that major differences in reduction result from interactions of nickel oxide with high surface area supports [4,6], the effect is not restricted to compound formation. Richardson et al. [7] show nickel oxide reduction is changed by incorporation of small (about 2 wt.-% ) amounts of additive oxides, so that ease of reduction is proportional to the ratio of the equilibrium constant for reduction of the added oxide to that for nickel oxide. Oxides that are easier to reduce than nickel oxide, such as Ag20 and CuO, accelerate reduction of NiO, whereas oxides such as A1203 and ZrO2, inhibit reduction. These effects are not so well documented for nickel oxide on a-AI203, commonly perceived to be "inert" and widely used as a support for steam reforming catalysts. Gavalas et al. [8,9] used hydrogen chemisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy on impregnated 2.2 wt.-% NiO/a-A1203. Calcination below 850 gives only NiO, but above 850 some precursor of NiA1204 forms and is insoluble in acid and difficult to reduce. This study suggests discrete NiO particles consist of rafts 100 to 200 nm in diameter and 30 nm thick. Similarly, Lamber and Schulz-Ekloff [ 10] found evidence for NiO and NiAI204, with epitaxial growth of NiO crystallites indicated for ),-alumina but not a-A1203. Reduction from 500 to 700 produces roughly spherical nickel crystallites surrounded by shells of NiA12Oa-type mate- J.T. Richardson et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General i10 (1994) 217-237 219 rial. For reduction at 800, there is an increase of the lattice parameters for Ni on a-A1203, suggesting incorporation of aluminum atoms into the structure. Another important parameter in nickel oxide reduction is flow-rate of hydrogen through the catalyst bed. Coenen [6] speculated the phenomenon is related to water inadequately removed from the surface at low flow-rates in the absence of mass transfer limitations. This paper describes studies on the kinetics and mechanism for reduction of ot-A1203- supported nickel oxide, with emphasis on the effects of NiO loading, hydrogen flow-rate and local concentrations of water. Several novel features resulting from this work have been reported in a brief communication [ 11 ] and this paper describes the details leading to those results. For example, techniques are used which effectively decouple chemical reduction and nickel crystallite growth, enabling these steps to be studied separately. In later papers we will report the effect of promoter oxides and supports commonly found in steam reform- ing catalysts. 2. Experimental 2.1. Sample preparation Catalysts containing between 5 and 21.3 wt.-% nickel oxide were prepared by impreg- nating preformed a-A1203 Raschig rings ( 1.7 cm diameter, 1.0 cm high) with a solution of Ni(NO3)2" 6H20 in deionized water, followed by drying at 120 and 6 h calcination in air at 650. With 3 M nickel nitrate solution (pH = 2.7), pore-filling during impregnation gives only about 5 wt.-% loading, so the impregnation/calcination was repeated several times to achieve higher loadings. The catalysts were ground in a TEMA agate mill and sieved to particles less than 100/xm in size. 2.2. Chemical analysis Loss on ignition at 900 was measured in air, and elemental analyses determined with a Philips PW 1400 X-ray fluorescence spectrophotometer. 2.3. Magnetic measurements Experimental techniques for measuring magnetization curves at different times of reduc- tion with an in situ sample cell have been described in detail earlier [7]. Experimental procedures were as follows. Approximately 80 mg of 150 mesh sample powder were loaded into the inner tube of the cell to form a bed 7 mm long. After purification by beds of reduced Harshaw 106 nickel catalyst and activated Linde 5A molecular sieve, helium was passed at 60 cm3 min- ~ for 20 min at 25 through the sample to remove traces of air and moisture. Measurement of magnetization versus magnetic field for the unreduced sample was made at 25 up to 14 kOe. Isothermal reduction measurements followed by placing the cell in an external furnace and reducing with purified hydrogen at temperatures from 270 to 330 and for time intervals varying from 5 min to several hours. After each treatment, the 220 J.T. Richardson et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 110 (1994) 217-237 sample was cleaned with helium and magnetic measurements repeated with a precision of _ 2%. Magnetization curves were then analyzed to give the extent of reduction [7]. 2.4. X-ray diffraction A Siemens D 5000 high temperature X-ray diffraction system with a position sensitive detector was used to identify the type and amount of each crystalline phase present in the samples. Nickel oxide crystallite sizes were determined from XRD line broadening using the Williamson and Hall modification of the Debye-Scherrer method [ 12]. Lattice para- meters for NiO were calculated by using ot-A1203 as an internal standard. 2.5. Temperature-programmed reduction Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) data were obtained with an apparatus com- prising two 4-mm stainless steel tubes (one a sample cell containing approximately 100 mg of catalyst packed between quartz wool, the other a reference cell with an equivalent bed of a-A1203). These were connected through mass flow controllers to a common gas supply, containing from 20% to 70% hydrogen in purified argon. Exit streams from each tube passed through small beds of silica gel to remove water and then to opposite sides of a thermal conductivity cell. A furnace surrounding the tubes was regulated within 2 by an Omega programmable temperature controller, which also provided a linear rate of temperature increase. The sample was loaded, dried by heating at 120 for 1-2 h in argon, and reduction started with a total flow of 40 cm3 min-' through the bed. Hydrogen consumed during reduction was recorded as a peak in the temperature scan. The sensitivity of the detector was calibrated by injecting hydrogen pulses into the carrier gas with a valve located before the sample cell. Recorded peaks were analyzed with PeakFit, a computer program from the Jandel Corporation, which deconvoluted overlapping peaks. 2.6. Hydrogen consumption kinetics The TPR apparatus was used in an isothermal mode to obtain hydrogen consumption kinetic data. With the hydrogen-containing stream ( 10 to 50 mol-%) flowing through the sample, the temperature was raised rapidly to the reduction temperature and held constant for the duration of the experiment. The isothermal peak recording hydrogen consumed during reduction was integrated to give the amount of hydrogen consumed at different times, from which the extent of reduction versus time data were calculated. A small error resulted from hydrogen consumed during the initial heating process, but this was never more than 3% of the total peak. 2. 7. Surface areas Surface areas were measured with a Quantachrome Quantasorb apparatus, using the single point BET method with nitrogen. Densities were obtained with a Quantachrome multi pycnometer. J.T. Properties of the unreduced catalysts General properties of the unreduced catalysts (Table 1) are consistent with a model in which nickel oxide crystallites deposit with increasing concentration upon the surface of a- A1203. Initially, there is an increase in total surface area and pellet density and a decrease in pore volume. The trends in pellet density and pore volume continue as loading increases, but the surface area passes through a maximum at about 9-10 wt.-% NiO. This reflects changes in the morphology of the NiO grains, the most important properties being size and shape. X-ray diffraction showed only the presence a-A1203 and NiO, with no indication of NiO- A1203 compound formation. Table 2 shows the lattice constants for NiO are essentially constant within experimental error and very close to 0.4177 nm for bulk NiO [ 13]. The amount of NiO estimated from quantitative analysis of the peak intensities was only about 80% of the NiO present, indicating a consistent fraction of undetected NiO amounting to about 20%. Presumably, this is some highly dispersed nickel compound, either NiO or nickel aluminate. Transmission electron microscopy studies on Catalyst D showed well crystalline a-AI203 particles ranging in size from 150 to 900 nm and decorated with discrete crystallites of NiO crystalline enough to yield sharp Laue spots with electron diffraction. There was also an assortment of very small NiO clusters less than 7 nm scattered over the surface. Significantly, there was no nickel detectable by energy dispersive spectroscopy in the alumina surface between NiO crystallites, suggesting the system comprises well-separated NiO crystallites rather than raft-like structures. A model for the unreduced catalysts may now be postulated. Apart from 20% of "unde- tected" NiO, the catalysts consist of large microcrystals of a-AI203 (about 103 nm) dec- orated with increasing amounts of discrete NiO crystallites all about the same size. Some of these crystallites are agglomerated into the larger grains seen by the transmission electron microscope. While the overall morphological features could be very complex, it is clear the NiO grains exist with shapes allowing a fraction of the a-A1203 surface to be uncovered. For example, if all the grains were single crystallites of a uniform size (30 nm), the support surface would be completely covered at a loading of about 18 wt.-% NiO. Crystallite agglomeration is necessary to account for incomplete coverage. 3.2. Temperature-programmed reduction TPR results are shown in Fig. 1. For the lowest loading (Catalyst A), reduction began at about 275 and peaked at 330. As NiO loading increased, an additional peak appeared with a maximum at 375. This peak increased in magnitude at higher NiO levels, but the original peak remained in the same position. In all cases, the amount of hydrogen consumed corresponded to complete reduction. A sample of 100% NiO prepared by decomposing nickel nitrate in air at 650 and measured under the same conditions showed a TPR peak with a maximum at 323. This sample had a NiO crystallite size of 42 nm. The data in Fig. 1 indicate successive deposition of NiO onto the a-A1203 surface, generating NiO grains more difficult to reduce than either bulk NiO or the initial products of impregnation. The TPR experiments were repeated in 20% H2 to improve precision, and the resulting peaks deconvoluted with three overlapping symmetrical Giddings functions. Fig. 2 shows an example of peak fitting for Catalyst E. The peaks are centered at 325, 365 and 440 (regression coefficient= 0.9980; standard error = 0.0163). Table 3 shows the relative per- centage in each peak, labeled 1, 2, and 3 respectively, for all catalysts. Peak No. 1 is centered from 317 to 328, with the exception of Catalyst G which is slightly higher. The percentage of NiO in this peak remains about the same. Peak No. 2 shows an increase in temperature position but with approximately the same percentage. Peak No. 3 is relatively small, but a definite trend towards higher temperatures occurs. Furthermore, 38% of the NiO in Catalyst D reduces at 270 (Table 4) and this may be the form reduced in Peak 1 of the TPR data in Table 3, i.e. similar to bulk NiO. Decreased reducibility of the NiO represented by Peaks 2 and 3 in Table 3 could be due to chemical interaction with the support or to larger NiO crystallites. If Peak 1 corresponds to about 30 nm NiO crystallites, then there would have to be over twice as many larger crystallites to account for the ratios in Table 3. This is inconsistent with the XRD data of Table 2 showing almost constant size. We conclude the decreased reducibility originates from chemical sources. This is supported by the fact that reduction of bulk NiO from 220 to 310 has an activation energy of 127 kJ mol-1, higher than Eq. 4. There is no evidence for NixmlyO4 formation that could result in decreased reducibility. Nickel oxide exists with the normal structure throughout the series, suggesting that support interactions are indeed subtle. Chen et al. [ 17] showed that impregnation of nickel salts on high-area alumina supports results in aluminum ions dissolving during impregnation at low pH and subsequently incorporating into crystallized NiO precursors. This could also be true for o~-A1203, the amount of incorporated A13 + ions increasing with loading as impregnation steps increase throughout the series, resulting in a systematic effect on the ease of reduction. This hypothesis was tested with a sample prepared in the same manner as Catalyst C, except the impregnating solution contained aluminum nitrate equivalent to 10% of the nickel nitrate. The TPR curves for this sample and Catalyst C are compared in Fig. 6. There is a significant increase in the higher-temperature portion of the hydrogen consumption peak, due to the high concentration of A13 + ions. X-ray diffraction showed no detectable nickel aluminate structures. These facts strengthen the argument that impregnating proce- dures for the original catalyst also gives this effect. 228 J.T. Magnetic measurements of growth Magnetization measurements detect superparamagnetic clusters of metallic nickel con- taining greater than twenty atoms [ 18] and differ from hydrogen consumption methods which monitor chemical reduction. Typical magnetization data for Catalyst D reduced at 270 in 155 cm3 min- ~ of hydrogen are shown in Fig. 7. There is an increasing amount of metallic nickel at larger reduction times, with magnetization curves characteristic of fairly large cry stallites. Plots of M/Ms (where Ms is the saturation magnetization at high fields) versus H/T (where H is the magnetic field and T the temperature) from data measured at 25 and - 196 did not superimpose. Since this is a necessary condition for superpara- magnetism [ 18], this sample contained nickel crystallites above the superparamagnetic range, i.e. about 20 nm. Consequently, these data were not suitable for size distribution analysis. Fig. 8 shows the amount of NiO converted to metallic nickel, calculated from the data in Fig. 7. Values ofm were found between 0.5 and 1.5, with the higher values favored at lower temperatures and hydrogen flow-rates. The Avrami model, as usually applied to solid state reactions, has been reviewed by Hulbert, who describes low values of m with nuclei growth mechanisms when the production rate of nuclei is low and diffusion of the nuclei to reaction sites controlling [20]. The value of the exponent depends on the geometry of the particle and the exact nucleation model. The theoretical significance of Eq. 5 and the shift from high to lower values as temperatures and flow-rates increase will be discussed in a future paper. The dashed line in Fig. 8 is hydrogen consumption data from Fig. 5 for 120 cm3 min- 1 with the time scale compressed by a factor of five to account for the difference in hydrogen composition (20% versus 100%). The effect of flow-rate and water Reduction inhibition at low hydrogen flow has been reported previously for bulk NiO [22] and NiO on silica [6]. External diffusion is usually not a viable explanation since J.T. Richardson et aL /Applied Catalysis A: General 110 (1994) 217-237 233 calculated hydrogen mass transfer rates are orders of magnitude higher than the lowest rates measured experimentally. Thermodynamic limitations are equally improbable since the equilibrium constant for Nit reduction at 270 is about 2.102 Coenen [6] reviewed the literature and concluded the effect is related to inhibition by water. Water molecules liberated by Ni-O bond reduction in our experiments amount to about 200-300 monolayers. Most of this water is released immediately, but a fraction of a monolayer could be retained as chemisorbed water or hydroxyl species. Desorption into the gas phase depletes these species, but water leaves the catalyst bed slowly at low gas flow-rates and removal of water molecules on the surface through equilibrium with the gas phase is retarded. This effect decreases as water removal from the bed accelerates with increasing gas flow-rate. The results given in Table 5 and Fig. 5 indicate a model in which water retained on the surface because of low flow-rates has two principal effects. The first is to limit the amount of Nit reduced without necessarily decreasing the rate of reduction. This would occur, for instance, if certain crystallites retained surface water and inhibited initial hydrogen adsorp- tion/dissociation. These crystallites do not reduce as long as the protective species are present. Other crystallites without adsorbed water reduce easily. We suggest that aluminum ions incorporated into Nit during impregnation are responsible for this selectivity toward water retention. The second effect of adsorbed water is to decrease the nucleation rate, possibly by restricting diffusion of Niatoms across the surface to sites where clusters form. This requires some degree of interaction between Niatoms and surface hydroxyl groups. Under extreme conditions where the concentration of adsorbed water is high and surface diffusion low, long induction times are encountered before Niatoms reassemble into discrete clusters. The reduction mechanism This research supports general reduction mechanisms in the literature but also adds important new features. Details of the mechanism steps are as follows. ( 1 ) Dissociation of hydrogen, which occurs first on NiO and then rapidly on the surface of nickel clusters as they become available. (2) Rupture of Ni-O bonds by hydrogen atoms, producing Niatoms and water mole- cules. Although rapid, this process may be retarded or accelerated by foreign cations in the NiO lattice or on the surface. Aluminum, which retards reduction, may originate during impregnation from support ions dissolved in the acidic solution. (3) Diffusion of Niatoms. Nickel atoms diffuse across the support surface away from the center of reduction. (4) Nucleation of Niatoms into metallic nickel clusters. Nickel atoms produced by chemical reduction nucleate into clusters of atoms. This process appears as an induction period, when metallic nickel is monitored magnetically, if the overall reduction rates are small at low temperatures. Water retained on the surface at low hydrogen flows or from water added to the reducing gas retards nucleation by limiting the diffusion process. (5) Growth of nickel clusters into crystallites. The final step in the overall reduction is growth into nickel crystallites large enough for detection by magnetic and XRD measure- ments. Growth after nucleation is rapid, so that "islands" of nickel atoms form large crystallites. Externally added water does not affect this process to any large extent. Steps (1), and (2) occur rapidly and follow a diffusion-free, shrinking core model. Step (4) is better described by an Avrami model with diffusion-controlled nucleation. At low hydrogen flows, water is not removed rapidly enough from the bed and surface hydroxyls 236 J.T. Richardson et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 110 (1994) 217-237 are retained, inhibiting hydrogen dissociation and hence reduction. Added water has a similar effect. These surface hydroxyls inhibit nucleation, and under appropriate conditions growth is much slower than hydrogen consumption. The difference between chemical reduction and crystallite growth rates decreases when less water is retained at increasing temperatures and is only significant from 270 to 400. Incorporation of A13 + ions into NiO could be the reason why a-A1203-supported catalysts reduced at higher temperatures than bulk NiO, possibly by retaining hydroxyl groups at higher temperatures. Other ions could have similar or more severe effects. 4. Conclusions The most significant result from this research is that, in the reduction of both bulk and supported NiO, rupture of Ni-O bonds and growth of subsequent Niatoms into metal crystallites are separated by an induction period in which small nickel clusters nucleate through a diffusion-controlled mechanism. Adsorbed water inhibits this nucleation so that under the right conditions, e.g. at low hydrogen flow-rates or low temperatures, the two processes may be observed separately. The second important result is that successive impregnation onto o~-A1203 makes the catalysts increasingly more difficult to reduce chemically but does not appear to affect crystallite growth. The fact that similar effects occur when A13 + ions are added to bulk and supported NiO supports the model that dissolution of A13 + ions during impregnation and subsequent incorporation into NiO crystallites may be responsible. Inhibition of nucleation is not so severe at higher reduction temperatures commonly used in commercial steam reforming ( > 500). However, it is possible that in the presence of promoters which increase surface water retention, such as CaO and MgO, the inhibiting effect of adsorbed water may move to higher temperatures. These features will be reported in a later publication. Acknowledgements This project was supported by a grant from ICI Katalco (Billingham, UK). We thank J. Kennerley and W.M. The effect of NiO loading (5–21 wt.-%) on the reduction of NiO/α-A2O3 catalysts, prepared by multiple impregnation of nickel nitrate solution followed by calcination at 650°C has been characterized usingtemperature-programmed reduction, isothermal hydrogen consumption, magnetization, X-raydiffraction, and electron microscopy. Magnetic measurements show crystallite growth is dependent on diffusion-controlled nucleation. Decreasing hydrogen flow has a profound effect on chemical reduction and nucleation but not on growth. Similar results are found with added water vapor. X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscope measurements reveal 23 nm nickel crystallites with some evidence for Al-Ni alloy formation.
